content.definition: Perforator veins are vessels that connect the superficial venous system to the deep venous system by traversing (perforating) the deep fascia. They contain valves that normally direct blood from superficial to deep systems. Incompetent perforators are a significant cause of chronic venous insufficiency and venous ulceration.

medial_leg_perforators.name: Cockett Perforators
medial_leg_perforators.location: Posterior tibial perforators in medial lower leg
medial_leg_perforators.levels: Cockett I (6-7 cm), II (13-14 cm), III (18-20 cm from sole)
medial_leg_perforators.significance: Most clinically important - associate with medial ulcers

medial_leg_perforators.name: Boyd Perforator
medial_leg_perforators.location: Below-knee, connects GSV to posterior tibial veins

other_perforators.name: Lateral Leg Perforators
other_perforators.significance: Less common but can cause lateral ulcers

structure: Direct perforators: connect superficial directly to deep system
Indirect perforators: pass through muscle before reaching deep veins
Contain 1-3 bicuspid valves directing flow deep
normal_function: Direct blood from superficial to deep system
Valves prevent reflux from deep to superficial
pathology: Incompetent valves allow reflux to superficial system
Create areas of high ambulatory venous pressure
Contribute to skin changes and ulceration

incompetent_perforators: Major contributor to chronic venous insufficiency
Source of recurrence after superficial vein treatment
ulcer_association: Cockett perforators: medial ankle ulcers (gaiter zone)

duplex_ultrasound: Bidirectional flow or outward reflux >500 ms
Map location relative to skin marks
clinical_examination: Varicose tributaries emanating from fascial level

learning_objectives: Name and locate major perforator groups (Cockett, Boyd, Dodd, Hunterian)
Know association between perforator location and ulcer location
clinical_pearls: Cockett I, II, III are the 'surgical' perforators - most clinically important
